title: 111_hr777
content: The Administrator of the Federal Emergency Management Agency is prohibited from updating flood maps until a community outreach plan is submitted to Congress. A new refundable credit for residential properties in expanded flood zones is proposed in the Internal Revenue Code. The tax code allows for a credit against the tax for eligible individuals who pay premiums for flood insurance under the National Flood Insurance Act. The credit is limited based on income, with a reduction determined by a specific ratio. The tax code provides a credit for individuals paying flood insurance premiums based on income, with a reduction determined by a specific ratio of modified adjusted gross income. The tax code offers a credit for individuals paying flood insurance premiums based on income, limited to a 4-year period after the effective date of a flood insurance rate map for qualified flood risk properties in designated areas. The tax code provides a credit for individuals paying flood insurance premiums for qualified flood risk properties in designated areas. The property must be outside of floodplain areas prior to map revision, and the taxpayer must own the property or have a binding contract for purchase or construction on the effective date of the updated map. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code and United States Code are made to reflect these changes. The amendments made by this section apply to flood insurance rate maps under the National Flood Insurance Act of 1968. Refunds or credits for overpayments of tax resulting from these changes can be made within one year of the enactment of this Act. The National Flood Insurance Act of 1968 is amended to include a grant program for communities to improve their community rating.
